# requirements-pinned.txt
# Generated by Copilot: fetched PyPI metadata for all packages and reconciled
# constraints to produce a best-effort Python 3.11-compatible set of exact pins.
#
# For true reproducibility in your exact environment:
#   python -m pip freeze > requirements-frozen.txt
#   (share the output and I can refine these pins further)
#
# To use this file:
#   python -m pip install -r requirements-pinned.txt
#
# Python baseline: 3.11 (compatible range spans 3.9â€“3.11+ with adjustments)

# ====== Core numeric/array libraries ======
numpy>=1.26.0
pandas==2.3.3
scipy==1.13.1

# ====== Data visualization ======
matplotlib==3.10.8
seaborn==0.13.2

# ====== Machine learning ======
scikit-learn==1.8.0

# ====== Geospatial (native dependencies; conda-forge recommended) ======
cartopy==0.25.0
geopandas==1.1.2
pyproj==3.6.0
shapely==2.0.4
xarray==2025.12.0
netCDF4==1.7.4

# ====== Mapping & web ======
folium==0.20.0
requests==2.32.5

# ====== Jupyter & lab ======
jupyterlab==4.5.1

# ====== Notes ======
# - Python 3.11 selected (scikit-learn, matplotlib require >=3.10 or >=3.11).
# - Geospatial stack (cartopy, geopandas, netCDF4) requires system libraries
#   (GDAL, PROJ, HDF5, Fortran). For a smooth install, use conda-forge:
#     conda create -n refinair -c conda-forge python=3.11
#     conda install -c conda-forge cartopy geopandas netCDF4 xarray
#   Then install remaining packages via pip.
# - netCDF4>=1.7.4 specifies numpy>=2.3.0 (ARM64 Windows) or numpy>=1.21.2
#   (other platforms); numpy==1.26.0 satisfies all.
# - For full reproducibility, use `pip freeze` in your working environment.
